The IMC_OverTemp signal shall be sent by the V850 in all Power Modes except 0. 
The signal is a periodic signal and not event based to ensure that also ECUs who booted up after the signal has been send receive the signal.

The signal indicates the IMC temperature by being set to 3 values : 
 - If the IMC temperature is within a Normal range, the signal is set to NORMAL.
 - If the IMC temperature increases beyond the Normal range and gets into a Warning range, the  
signal is set to WARNING and the IMC notifies that the unit will shut down in 2 minutes.
 - If the IMC temperature increases beyond the Warning range and gets into a Critical range, the  
signal is set to CRITICAL and the IMC notifies that the unit is in the Amnesty period and above the ESD but below the ESD_Amnesty limits.

EuCD Signal.
Range: 0 - 16777214 (0-FFFFFEh)
Resolution: 1 KM
FFFFFFh = Invalid Data

                                                                         
NB: Signals greater than 16bits have to be of Signal Type (Bytes) as VSX does not support Unsigned signals >16bits.

The MSB of the signal must be written to the COM layer first (with an offset of zero in wr_bytes() ) and therefore transmitted on the bus first.
Similarly, subscribing modules will receive the MSB of the signal when they call rd_bytes(0).

E.g. wr_bytes(0) = published_signal_MSB;

Subscribed_Signal_MSB = rd_bytes(0);

The Occupant classification is determined by the combination of the signals OCSPassSeatOccupied and OCSPassWeightEst. Only 2 states are affected by the status of the Passenger Seat Belt Status, which means that an Empty status is overriden to Inhibit status if the Passenger seat belt status is Buckled and  an Inhibit status is overriden to Empty if the Passenger seat belt status is Unbuckled if and only if the pressure correspond to an Empty classification.

Once the classification is determined by the OCS those 2 bytes are used by the RCM to determine if the AIR bag should be deploy or not, that decision is taken by the RCM, the OCS only transmit the classification. 

OCSPassSeatOccupied=0x00 & OCSPassWeightEst=0x00 : Empty, Deployment inhibited.
 
OCSPassSeatOccupied=0x01 & OCSPassWeightEst=0x00 : Occupied Disabled, Deployment inhibited.

OCSPassSeatOccupied=0x00 & OCSPassWeightEst=0x01 : Indeterminate, Default value.

OCSPassSeatOccupied=0x01 & OCSPassWeightEst=0x01 : Occupied Enable Small, deployment allowed.

Message used by IPK and ETS to display selected gear information.TCM will set multiple bits when e.g in Drive 5th gear and in Sport. The Signal TCMDrivingModeDisplay can be used for gear 1-8 display when in manual mode.

Init: Blank ETS display and Blank IPK display. Bit 14 and 15 set to 1, all other bits set to 0 (49152 decimal)

Bits 0 - 5: Gear Selection
000000 = Auto selection
000001 = 1st Gear
000010 = 2nd Gear
000100 = 3rd Gear
001000 = 4th Gear
010000 = 5th Gear
100000 = 6th Gear
100001 = 7th Gear
100010 = 8th Gear
100100 = 9th Gear

Bits 6 - 11: Gear Mode
000001 = Fault
000010 = Park Position
000100 = Reverse Position
001000 = Neutral Position
010000 = Drive Position
100000 = Sport Position

Bits 12 - 13: Flash Display
x1 = FLASH ETS Display
1x = FLASH IPK Display

Bits 14 - 15: Blank Display
x1 = Blank ETS Display
1x = Blank IPK Display

Raw Rolling Count (counts through zero) of two front wheel speed signals.
Measures distance travelled based on a reference circumference listed below and a tooth ring with number of teeth listed below.
Calculated by counting both the rising and falling edges of the raw sensor signals from the two front wheel speed signals. 

ODORawCount does not indicate a default condition in the CAN signal. This may be determined
from other signals e.g. WheelSpeedFrRQF and WheelSpeedFrLQF.

The distance travelled per increment of this signal is hardware dependant based on the rolling circumference
(assumed and actual) and the number of teeth on the wheel speed sensor tooth ring.

For teeth values for specific carlines please contact the ABS team- Tim Reynolds (treyno13)

Example calculation:
Average distance travelled per increment  = [Rolling circ] / ( [Teeth] x 2 <signal edges> x 2 <wheels> )

LIN signal from steering wheel Joypad to instrument cluster to indicate that the Joypad DOWN button is being pressed.

4 bit rolling count, starting at zero.  Counts up by 1 every time switch is pressed and also every time switch is released.  So first time switch is pressed the count changes from 0 to 1, and when the switch is released the count changes from 1 to 2.  An even number (lsb = 0) therefore means that the switch is not pressed, and an odd number (lsb = 1) means the switch is pressed.  If count is 15 while switch is pressed, count becomes 0 when switch is released.

LIN signal from steering wheel Joypad to instrument cluster to indicate that the Joypad CENTRE button is being pressed.

4 bit rolling count, starting at zero. Counts up by 1 every time switch is pressed and also every time switch is released. So first time switch is pressed the count changes from 0 to 1, and when the switch is released the count changes from 1 to 2. An even number (lsb = 0) therefore means that the switch is not pressed, and an odd number (lsb = 1) means the switch is pressed. If count is 15 while switch is pressed, count becomes 0 when switch is released.

Message used by IPK and ETS to display selected gear information.TCM will set multiple bits when e.g in Drive 5th gear and in Sport. The Signal TCMDrivingModeDisplay can be used for gear 1-8 display when in manual mode.

Init: Blank ETS display and Blank IPK display. Bit 14 and 15 set to 1, all other bits set to 0 (49152 decimal)

Bits 0 - 5: Gear Selection
000000 = Auto selection
000001 = 1st Gear
000010 = 2nd Gear
000100 = 3rd Gear
001000 = 4th Gear
010000 = 5th Gear
100000 = 6th Gear
100001 = 7th Gear
100010 = 8th Gear
100100 = 9th Gear

Bits 6 - 11: Gear Mode
000001 = Fault
000010 = Park  Position
000100 = Reverse Position
001000 = Neutral Position
010000 = Drive Position
100000 = Sport Position 

Bits 12 - 13: Flash Display
x1 = FLASH ETS Display
1x = FLASH IPK Display

Bits 14 - 15: Blank Display
x1 = Blank ETS Display
1x = Blank IPK Display


On Electronic Shifter installations, the TCMPositionDisplay CAN message will indicate Park as follows:      - at ignition on the signal will indicate 'in Park' (128) if park is selected regardless of parklock status     - after ignition off the signal will indicate 'in Park' (128) if park is selected and parklock is confirmed, after ignition off the signal will indicate 'flash' and 'in Park' (not 128) if Park is selected but the Parklock is not confirmed for any reason. This is to communicate Parklock status to the BCM for Rollaway warnings. Please note that Park will not be engaged unless the vehicle speed is less than 2kph.

A rolling count (counts through zero) of distance travelled.
In steps of 0.000125 miles
00h = 0 miles
FEh = 0.03175 miles travelled since last roll-over.

RWD / AWD Vehicles:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Derived primarily from the two driven rear wheels. If one wheel speed sensor fails, the speed
Information from the other sensor is used. If both rear speed sensors fail, the signal defaults.

4WD Vehicles: 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Derived from the four driven wheels. In the case of wheel speed sensor failures, speed
information from the remaining sensors is used instead. If all four speed sensors fail, the signal
defaults.

4WD BEV Vehicles:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Derived from the four driven wheels. In the case of wheel speed sensor failures, speed
information from the remaining sensors is used instead. If all four speed sensors fail, the signal
defaults.

FWD / AWD Vehicles:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Derived primarily from the two driven front wheels. If one wheel speed sensor fails, the speed
information from the other sensor is used. If both rear speed sensors fail, the signal defaults.

Rolling circumference values used in vehicle speed calculation differ per carline.

This signal indicates the virtual accelerator pedal position with respect to a particular pedal mapping. This signal will represent a different value to PedalPos whilst in cruise, as the cruise system will increase engine torque without the physical pedal moving.

This signal represents the 'drive mode compensated' accelerator pedal position. The 'drive mode compensated' accelerator pedal position includes profiling for the currently selected drive mode (Terrain Response Mode or Jaguar Drive Control Mode).
TMPedalPos may not be equal to PedalPos in some or all of the Drive Modes, and will depend upon the calibration of the Accelerator Pedal profiling within the ECM.
Upon Drive Mode change, the value of TMPedalPos will filter or ramp from the current pedal profile towards the target pedal profile for the new Drive Mode. 
Note that the TMPedalPos can have a change in value with constant accelerator pedal position upon selection of a new Drive Mode.

To inform the DIM about actual TVB function status against brake temperature. Temporarily.

0 = Temperature Threshold not exceeded
1 = Temperature Threshold is exceeded - Driver warning message is to be displayed.

1 bit signal used to indicate that ABS is unable to generate any/ sufficient brake vacuum using the electric vacuum pump, and that the engine will need to generate brake vacuum itself.

Use in conjunction with VehicleSpeedQF. A value of 65535d may also be set under error conditions.
 
Rear Wheel Drive and AWD Vehicles: VehicleSpeed is calculated as the average speed of the two driven rear wheels. If one wheel speed sensor fails, VehicleSpeed will use the speed information from the other sensor.  

Four Wheel Drive Vehicles: VehicleSpeed is calculated as the average speed of all four wheels. In the case of wheel speed sensor failures, VehicleSpeed will use the speed information from the remaining sensors.

Front Wheel Drive and AWD Vehicles: VehicleSpeed is calculated as the average speed of the two driven front wheels. If one wheel speed sensor fails, VehicleSpeed will use the speed information from the other sensor.

This is the logical output of the plausibility and validation of Driver PRNDS Requests, made by the driver via the GSM (Gear selector Module), against prevailing transmission shift interlocks. 
This output includes:
 a) 'Interrupt' values, that result from locked PRNDS requests made by the driver or other movements of the Gear selector that may represent intentional movement of the gear selector to influence vehicle operating state.
b) Valid requests for PRNDS made by the driver having satisfied all the prevailing driver transmission shift interlocks (Brake pedal and unlock trigger) - re-request values are used to ensure repeated requests for the same range cause a state change within the Shift-by-wire & ADAS systems)
The GSA intention for this feedback is for the LMC to monitor for any change in state and take the appropriate interrupting action to the ADAS system/features.

The estimated Rear Left and Rear Right Wheel Brake Torque component for Torque Vectoring by Braking (TVB). Excludes brake torque generated by other controller functions or by the driver. The value of this message is affected by the TVB override scaling request message; therefore, will be scaled between 0Nm & 100Nm depending on the value given by the TvBOverrideScalReq message. It will be ramped down to 0Nm when the TVBOverride flag is set.

0-126 = Left delivered brake torque (0=-1270Nm 126=-10Nm), 127 = 0Nm (no delivered TVB activation), 128-254 = Right delivered brake torque, (128=+10Nm, 254 = +1270Nm)

This signal indicates the direction of steering wheel rotation.

This signal provides the a measurement of the steering wheel position. The angle is measured as referenced from a 0 degree straight-ahead position. 

- If the steering wheel is rotated clockwise, the measurement decreases.
- If the steering wheel is rotated anti-clockwise, the measurement increases.

On certain vehicle lines fitted with relative angle sensors, the straight-ahead position may have to be 'learned' in each ignition cycle after a brief period of driving. On vehicles fitted with absolute angle sensors, this is not the case.

Depending on the vehicle electrical architecture, the signal may be sourced via the ABS module or direct from the SASM.

The MSB of the signal must be written to the COM layer first (with an offset of zero in wr_bytes() ) and therefore transmitted on the bus first.
Similarly, subscribing modules will receive the MSB of the signal when they call rd_bytes(0).

E.g. wr_bytes(0) = published_signal_MSB;

Subscribed_Signal_MSB = rd_bytes(0);

2-bit signal relating to SteeringWheelAngleUnsigned. This flag indicates progress with the Learn Centre Algorithm. This signal will indicate a value of 1 (Centre not learned) at the start of every ignition cycle before the algorithm has had a chance to run. As the algorithm runs to completion, the value will increment to 3. Certain exceptional conditions may cause the algorithm to re-run mid-igntion cycle. A fault with the sensor is indicated by a value of 0.
